p: P. graveolens’ essential oil showed a significant antibacterial activity (85%) against E. coli in 100% concentration. In lower concentrations, it did not affect E. coli growth. On the other hand, the extract showed good antibacterial activity (68%) against E. coli in 90% concentration and average efficacy in 50% and 25% concentrations (59% and 46% respectively). As for S. aureus, the essential oil had good antibacterial activity (55%) in 100% concentration. In lower concentrations, it was not effective. The extract was not effective against this bacterium—only in 90% concentration it appeared to have a minor inhibition (40%). Finally, the essential oil had a small activity against Salmonella spp. (51%), in 100% concentration. In lower concentrations, its activity was negligible. The extract was almost efficient in 90%, 42%, while in lower concentrations, it had no effect.
